name: Nausea and Vomiting
question1: Define Nausea and vomiting. Describe the physiology of vomiting
contents:
Nausea - the sensation of the need to vomit

Vomiting - the involuntary, forceful expulsion of gastric contents via the mouth


Vomiting is the active, forceful expulsion of gastric contents from the stomach. It is different from regurgiation which is a passive process.


The physiology of vomiting is complex with multiple afferent and efferent pathways;

  • The Chemoreceptor Trigger Zone (CTZ)
  • lies in the floor of the fourth ventricle in the area postrema and is functionally outside the BBB.
  • Dopamine (D2) and
  • Serotonin 5HT3 receptors
  • Other input to the Vomiting centre
  • Cerebral cortex (pain, fear, sight, smell, memory, anticipation)
  • Vestibular system VIII (vestibulo-coclear)
  • Acetylcholine (ACh) is important in neural transmission from the vestibular apparatus.
  • Cardiovascular - Baroreceptors X (vagus)
  • Intestinal chemoreceptors X (vagus)
  • Peripheral pain pathways


The treatment of nausea and vomiting is aimed at reducing the afferent supply to the VC.
question2: Describe the process of vomiting (2) sub (7), Potential complications of vomiting
contents2:
Divided into two phases:

  • Pre-ejection phase
  • Nausea
  • Sympathetic stimulation - tachycardia, tachyponea, sweating
  • Parasympathetic stimulation - salivation, upper and lower oesophageal sphincter relax, giant retrograde contraction of the small intestine.
  • Ejection phase
  • (1) Respiration temporarily ceases mid-inspiration
  • (2) Hyoid and larynx raise to open the crico-oesophageal sphincter
  • (3) Glottis closes
  • (4) Soft palate elevates to close off nasopharynx
  • (5) Contraction of diaphgram and abdominal muscles results in a rise in intra-abdominal pressure.
  • (6) Gastro-oesophageal sphincter opens
  • (7) Ejection of gastric contents.

Potential complications

  • Aspiration particularly if low GCS
  • Wound dehiscence
  • Electrolyte imbalance (loss of H+, K+ and chloride)
  • Dehydration
  • Elevated intraocular and ICP.
question3: What are the main risk factors for PONV? categorise (3)
contents3:
Patient factors

  • Female
  • Non-smoker
  • Previous PONV
  • History of motion sickness

Anaesthetic factors

  • Use of N20
  • Use of opiates
  • Use of etomiodate
  • Use of neostigmine
  • Hypotension

Surgical factors

  • Middle ear surgery
  • Opthalmic surgery (especially squint surgery)
  • Gynacological
